conclusion: Determine the length of the transparent part of the hemispherical lens through which light enters perpendicularly to the vertical diameter MN.
The light source is at the focal point F of the paraboloid.
The paraboloid reflects light such that it travels parallel to the axis of symmetry and enters the hemispherical lens perpendicularly to the vertical diameter MN.
The hemispherical lens has a radius R.
Since the light enters the lens perpendicularly to the vertical diameter MN, it means that the light rays are parallel to the axis of symmetry of the paraboloid and the vertical diameter MN.
The light rays that enter the lens perpendicularly will do so across a certain width of the lens.
The light rays entering perpendicularly will strike the lens along a horizontal line that is parallel to the diameter MN.
The transparent part of the lens is essentially the horizontal chord of the hemisphere that is perpendicular to MN.

The chord length L of a circle (or hemisphere in this case) can be calculated using the formula for a chord length in terms of the radius R and the perpendicular distance d from the center of the circle to the chord: L = 2 sqrt(R^2 - d^2)
Since the light enters perpendicularly to the diameter MN, the distance d is 0 (as the light enters at the maximum width of the hemisphere).
Given that d = 0, the formula simplifies to: L = 2 sqrt(R^2 - 0^2) = 2R
The length of the transparent part of the lens through which light enters perpendicularly is 2R.
